Like many of us, I have watched the immense human tragedy in Afghanistan in horror. My heart goes out to the Afghan people, especially the many Afghans who risked their lives for a safer, freer Afghanistan... https://t.co/3JB9aaxpSo

The Biden Administration just increased food stamp benefits by 25% ‚Äîthe largest long-term increase in the program's history.

https://t.co/Pzt2RfL7gE
I agree with President Biden: an endless American military occupation of Afghanistan was unacceptable.

We must begin to prove that with this airlift operation, and then I look forward to working with him to ensure that when the headlines and emotions of this deeply painful moment subside, we are still focused on the people to whom we owe an enormous amount.

There will also be Afghan human rights activists, and women, and civil society who choose to stay. We have an obligation to them, too. The President has been clear that the end of the war does not mean the end of our commitment to the Afghan people.

In the meantime, the urgency of the moment before us now demands we marshal an international coalition to evacuate every Afghan citizen who is fleeing for their lives. This is an American responsibility, and it is also a NATO responsibility, and it is also a human responsibility.
There will be plenty of time for confronting the fundamental failures of our Afghanistan policy over the course of many decades and four presidencies.
...as well the of countless Americans who served in this conflict, thousands of whom made the ultimate sacrifice.

I hope we genuinely confront them, and reckon with them, rather than doubling down on obsolete talking points from 20 years ago that fail to account for the thousands of American lives cost and trillion-plus dollars spent. I hope we will learn from this, as painful as it is.

It has also, for me, been personally painful. I know what it‚Äôs like to be the child in the family scrambling for safety in a war-torn country. I also know intimately the difference between making it out and not making it out.
We must hold the airport in Kabul and lead a multinational airlift operation. We have the capacity, and we must find the will to get them out.
Violence only produces trauma, trauma that can turn into anger, vengefulness and a continuing cycle of violence. That must be a lesson as we deal with conflicts around the world.

Of course, the tragedy did not begin in the last couple of weeks. The hard truth about America‚Äôs longest war is that for 20 years, we made promises we couldn‚Äôt keep. The simple fact is that prolonging a war indefinitely would not have delivered a stable, peaceful Afghanistan.
War and conflict never produce peace and stability. Violence and militarism, even when cloaked in the language of humanitarianism, are fundamentally at odds with human flourishing and opportunity.
As with so many moments in this two-decade long conflict, I have not been able to read the news without seeing myself and my family, many years ago, desperately fleeing imminent violence in Somalia.

Today marks one year since the attacks of January 6th. I will never forget the experience of fearing for my life, my fellow members, and staff on a day designed to show the strength of our democracy.
"A democracy is more than a form of government; it is primarily a mode of associated living, of conjoint communicated experience," John Dewey once said.
Trust in our government‚Äôs ability to tackle the biggest problems we face‚Äîfrom healthcare to climate to food insecurity‚Äîhas cratered as a result.
But it also requires reforming our institutions so that they are once again responsive to the core demands of our constituents.
With each passing day, it becomes more and more clear that the outgoing President of the United States planned and executed the coup attempt...
The coup attempt on January 6th was a warning for what‚Äôs to come if we don‚Äôt act. The work to prevent the next coup begins now.
I will never forget the call I made to the father of my children, asking him to tell my children I loved them if I couldn‚Äôt.
Borrowing from demagogues around the world, authoritarians like Donald Trump filled the void, offering false promises while scapegoating immigrants, and religious and racial minorities.
I know personally what happens when a government fails, civil strife takes hold, and people are displaced. And I know that coup attempts are rarely one-time affairs.

refusing a peaceful transition of power, pressuring election officials and his own administration to overturn results, and organizing a rally and march on the seat of government when his other efforts failed.

To stop the next coup, we must reinvigorate the democratic experience. That requires, at a minimum, passing the John Lewis Voting Rights Act and strengthening election laws around the country to prevent the next coup.

That requires abolishing fundamentally antidemocratic elements of our system like the Senate filibuster and the electoral college, and it requires major investments in childcare, education, health and climate like the Build Back Better Act.

Inequality has skyrocketed, as has the cost of basics like healthcare and education, while the average American‚Äôs wages have not kept pace. Self-interested elites have prioritized profit and greed over the common good.
In fact, as we speak, Donald Trump‚Äôs allies in statehouses across the country are seeking to erect barriers to voting‚Äîlargely affecting low-income people, people of color, and seniors.

If that‚Äôs not enough, they are stripping power from nonpartisan election officials and rewriting state laws to seize partisan control over election certification. The next coup is not only possible; it has already begun.

No, January 6th was significant because it was an attack on the seat of our democracy, specifically designed to undermine, interrupt and overturn the most fundamental of democratic processes‚Äîan election‚Äîon the day its results were to be certified.

But the causes of the attempts to overturn our democracy run much deeper than Donald Trump. For decades, our institutions have been failing to meet the needs of the people they are tasked to represent.

Two years. 

For two years we have been marching. For two years we have called for accountability for aggressive policing. For two years we have called for a system where everyone can live free from fear of violence.
We need to address the root causes of injustice by investing in schools, housing, healthcare, and jobs.

I want to thank President Biden for taking steps in addressing the demands of criminal justice advocates this week, including a national database of police misconduct, strict limits on the use of chokeholds and anti-bias training.

Public safety‚Äîan essential function of our government‚Äîtoo often means resources without reform for police departments. The Senate has still not passed the George Floyd Justice and Policing Act, or even a more modest bipartisan criminal justice reform package.

The student debt relief application is now LIVE.  

Here‚Äôs a breakdown of what you need to know: (thread)

Where do I apply for student loan forgiveness?

You can apply now at https://t.co/AhTSkVgXyf

How long will the form take to fill out?

The form will take about 5 minutes to submit.

Our Republican colleagues are making it perfectly clear: they want to cut taxes for greedy corporations and billionaires. 

We can‚Äôt let them steal from the middle and working class to benefit their wealthy donors.¬†¬†

https://t.co/hJc4NftF1M

Do parent plus loans qualify for cancellation?

Yes. Parent Plus loans are eligible under the forgiveness plan. 

If a parent received a Parent Plus loan on behalf of a student and the same student received a direct loan, BOTH can qualify for student loan forgiveness.

How much of my student loans will be cancelled?

Federal Pell Grant recipients will receive up to $20,000 and non-Pell Grant recipients will receive up to $10,000.

How do I know if I‚Äôm eligible to receive relief? 

You will qualify if you made less than $125,000 in 2021 or 2020 or families that made less than $250,000 in 2021 or 2020.

When will my application be processed after submitting?

Your loan servicer will notify you when your relief has been processed. The Biden Admin has said that applicants will receive relief within 4 to 6 weeks after it begins processing applications.

When do I need to apply to receive forgiveness?

You can apply now or no later than December 21, 2023. But, the Admin recommends you apply before Nov 15 to have the form processed before the pause on federal student loan payments ends.

What information is needed to fill out the student debt forgiveness form?

Applicants will need to submit their name, Social Security number, date of birth, phone number, email, and attest to earning less than the income eligibility requirements.
